citing_paper_authors: Advaith, Siddharthan | Ani, Nenkova | Kathleen R., McKeown

raw_text: In fact, professional abstractors tend to use these operations to transform selected sentences from an article into the corresponding summary sentences (Jing, 2000)
clean_text: In fact, professional abstractors tend to use these operations to transform selected sentences from an article into the corresponding summary sentences (Jing, 2000).

raw_text: For example, Jing (2000) trained her system on a set of 500 sentences from the Benton Foundation (http: //www.benton.org) and their reduced forms written by humans
clean_text: For example, Jing (2000) trained her system on a set of 500 sentences from the Benton Foundation (http: //www.benton.org) and their reduced forms written by humans.

raw_text: Examples include text summarisation (Jing 2000), subtitle generation from spoken transcripts (Vandeghinste and Pan 2004) and information retrieval (Olivers and Dolan 1999)
clean_text: Examples include text summarisation (Jing 2000), subtitle generation from spoken transcripts (Vandeghinste and Pan 2004) and information retrieval (Olivers and Dolan 1999).

raw_text: Jing (2000) was perhaps the first to tackle the sentence compression problem
clean_text: Jing (2000) was perhaps the first to tackle the sentence compression problem.

raw_text: Our constraints are linguistically and semantically motivated in a similar fashion to the grammar checking component of Jing (2000)
clean_text: Our constraints are linguistically and semantically motivated in a similar fashion to the grammar checking component of Jing (2000).

raw_text: Jing and McKeown (H. Jing, 2000) studied a new method to remove extraneous phrase from sentences by using multiple source of knowledge to decide which phrase in the sentences can be removed
clean_text: Jing and McKeown (H. Jing, 2000) studied a new method to remove extraneous phrase from sentences by using multiple source of knowledge to decide which phrase in the sentences can be removed.

raw_text: Sentence compression is the task of producing a shorter form of a single given sentence, so that the new form is grammatical and retains the most important information of the original one (Jing, 2000) .Sentence compression is valuable in many applications, for example when displaying texts on small screens (Corston-Oliver, 2001), in subtitle generation (Vandeghinste and Pan, 2004), and in text summarization (Madnani et al, 2007)
clean_text: Sentence compression is the task of producing a shorter form of a single given sentence, so that the new form is grammatical and retains the most important information of the original one (Jing, 2000).

raw_text: Sentence compression is the task of summarizing a sentence while retaining most of the informational content and remaining grammatical (Jing, 2000) .In extractive sentence compression, which we focus on in this paper, an order-preserving subset of the words in the sentence are selected to form the summary, that is, we summarize by deleting words (Knight and Marcu, 2002)
clean_text: Sentence compression is the task of summarizing a sentence while retaining most of the informational content and remaining grammatical (Jing, 2000).

raw_text: Sentence compression is the task of producing ashorter form of a grammatical source (input) sentence, so that the new form will still be grammatical and it will retain the most important information of the source (Jing, 2000)
clean_text: Sentence compression is the task of producing a shorter form of a grammatical source (input) sentence, so that the new form will still be grammatical and it will retain the most important information of the source (Jing, 2000).

citing_paper_authors: Stefan, Riezler | Tracy Holloway, King | Richard, Crouch | Annie, Zaenen
raw_text: To overcome this problem, linguistic parsing and generation systems are used in the sentence condensation approaches of Knight and Marcu (2000) and Jing (2000) .In these approaches, decisions about which material to include/delete in the sentence summaries do not rely on relative frequency information on words, but rather on prob ability models of subtree deletions that are learned from a corpus of parses for sentences and their summaries
clean_text: To overcome this problem, linguistic parsing and generation systems are used in the sentence condensation approaches of Knight and Marcu (2000) and Jing (2000). In these approaches, decisions about which material to include/delete in the sentence summaries do not rely on relative frequency information on words, but rather on probability models of subtree deletions that are learned from a corpus of parses for sentences and their summaries.

citing_paper_authors: Stefan, Riezler | Tracy Holloway, King | Richard, Crouch | Annie, Zaenen
raw_text: In addition, an automatic evaluation method based on context-free deletion decisions has been proposed by Jing (2000)
clean_text: In addition, an automatic evaluation method based on context-free deletion decisions has been proposed by Jing (2000).

raw_text: Sentence compression produces a summary of a single sentence that retains the most important information while remaining grammatical (Jing, 2000) .Ideally, we would like a text-to-text rewriting system that is not application specific
clean_text: Sentence compression produces a summary of a single sentence that retains the most important information while remaining grammatical (Jing, 2000).

raw_text: A syntactic approach considers the alignment over parse trees (Jing, 2000), and a similar technique has been used with dependency trees to evaluate the quality of sentence fusions (Marsi and Krahmer, 2005)
clean_text: A syntactic approach considers the alignment over parse trees (Jing, 2000), and a similar technique has been used with dependency trees to evaluate the quality of sentence fusions (Marsi and Krahmer, 2005).
